Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of CEA-Specific Fluorescence Imaging in Cytoreductive Surgery for Colorectal Cancer

Trial_Design.evidence: Fourteen patients with peritoneal metastases of colorectal origin were included.

Participants.evidence: patients with peritoneal metastasized colorectal cancer

Intervention.evidence: SGM-101 was administered intravenously 4–6 days before surgery.

Objective.evidence: This multicentre pilot study evaluated the effectiveness of carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA)-specific fluorescence imaging using SGM-101 during cytoreductive surgery.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the change in the peritoneal carcinomatosis index (PCI) due to fluorescence imaging, measured intraoperatively.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation and blinding details were not applicable as this was a pilot study.

Blinding.evidence: Randomisation and blinding details were not applicable as this was a pilot study.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Fourteen patients with peritoneal metastases of colorectal origin were included.

Number_Analysed.evidence: A correct change in PCI due to fluorescence imaging was observed in 4 of the 14 patients.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The sensitivity and specificity of fluorescence imaging were 98.5% and 62.2%, respectively, with an accuracy of 85.4%.

Harms.evidence: SGM-101 was well tolerated, with no adverse events reported.

Trial_Registration.evidence: No trial registration or funding details were provided.

Funding.evidence: No trial registration or funding details were provided.
